question.text: The proportion of the offsprings obtained from the cross <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>×</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></math> will be completely heterozygous for all genes segregated independently will be

solution.text:
As per Mendel's Law of Segregation "alleles segregate randomly into gametes: When gametes are formed, each allele of one parent segregates randomly into the gametes, such that half of the parent's gametes carry each allele."

The cross between parents with genotype produces the following progenies -

ABBCC×AaBbCc

AABBCC

AABBCc

AABbCC

AABbCc

AaBBCC

AaBbCc

AaBBCc

AaBbCC

Progeny with genotype heterozygous for all gene is 1 out of 8 types. Thus, probability is 1/8
